title: Effects of auditory distance cues and reverberation on spatial perception and listening strategies
author: Fulvio Missoni (University of Genoa), Katarina Poole (Imperial College London), Lorenzo Picinali (Imperial College London), Andrea Canessa (University of Genoa), ...
relevance_why: This study investigates spatial hearing mechanisms in reverberant environments, which can inform techniques in audio processing and the development of audio enhancement tools for improved spatial perception.
background: Understanding how distance and reverberation affect spatial auditory perception helps in designing better audio devices and environments.
contribution: This paper introduces a framework to analyze the influence of listener movement and acoustic conditions on sound localization accuracy, revealing adaptive strategies employed by listeners in variable environments.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous studies primarily examined static conditions or contained limited variability in acoustic environments during listening tasks.
technical_comparison.novelty: This study incorporates dynamic listener movements and a broader range of acoustic conditions, enhancing ecological validity in the research of spatial hearing.

key_innovation: Focuses on the adaptive use of head movements in reverberant environments to compensate for auditory uncertainty, providing insights into human acoustic navigation.
real_world_impact: The findings could inform the design of better auditory systems, such as hearing aids and spatial audio systems, ensuring enhanced performance in real-world acoustic settings.
limitations: The study sample size is small and predominantly composed of young adults, which may limit the generalizability of the findings.

new_terms.head-related transfer function (HRTF): **Head-related transfer function (HRTF)** represents how the shape of the ear and head interact with sound waves coming from different directions, affecting sound localization.
